UserStory.DescriptionZH: 玩家可以躲避攻击
UserStory.INVEST:
Independent: Yes, because the "Dodge" feature can be implemented as a standalone system that is not dependent on other game features or systems.
Negotiable: Yes, because the specifics of how the "Dodge" feature works (e.g. how fast the player moves, how many times they can dodge in a row, etc.) can be adjusted based on the team's resources and priorities.
Valuable: Yes, because the "Dodge" feature can enhance the player's ability to avoid obstacles or enemy attacks, making the game more engaging and rewarding.
Estimable: Yes, because the level of effort required to implement the "Dodge" feature can be estimated based on the complexity of the desired mechanics and the resources available to the team.
Small: Yes, because the "Dodge" feature can be implemented as a relatively isolated and straightforward system that is not overly complex.
Testable: Yes, because the team can create test cases to ensure that the "Dodge" feature functions correctly and is balanced with the rest of the game mechanics.

Tests.Test: Press the corresponding key for Dodge and check if the player performs a dodge.
Perform a dodge during enemy attacks and check if the attack is avoided.

UserStory.Label: Should Have

UserStory.heading: Difficulties
UserStory.Description: As a player, I would like the game to offer more than one difficulty level (perhaps three), so that it can cater to different types of players.
UserStory.DescriptionZH: 游戏能提供不止一种（或许三种）难度级别
UserStory.INVEST:
Independent: No, because the implementation of different difficulty levels may rely on other systems or features in the game, such as enemy AI or level design.
Negotiable: Yes, because the exact number and names of the difficulty levels can be adjusted based on the team's resources and priorities.
Valuable: Yes, because offering multiple difficulty levels can increase player engagement and satisfaction by allowing players to tailor the game experience to their own skill level.
Estimable: No, because the level of effort required to implement multiple difficulty levels depends on the complexity of the game systems and may require significant development time.
Small: No, because implementing multiple difficulty levels is a significant feature that may require a dedicated team effort.
Testable: Yes, because the team can create test cases to ensure that each difficulty level offers a unique and appropriate level of challenge for players.

Tests.Test: Test by modifying the game difficulty in the difficulty menu and checking if the game difficulty indicator changes.
Enter the game using different difficulty levels and check if there are any differences in the game difficulty.

UserStory.Description: As a player, I would like the game to have a Save feature, so that I can keep my progress even after quitting the game.
UserStory.DescriptionZH: 游戏可以进行存档，在重新进入游戏时不会丢失进度
UserStory.INVEST:
Independent: No, because the implementation of game saves requires integration with other game systems such as save/load functionality, storage management, and potentially network connectivity.
Negotiable: Yes, because the specific save/load functionality can be adjusted based on the team's resources and priorities. For example, the team can choose to implement manual save points or an automatic checkpoint system.
Valuable: Yes, because the ability to save and continue the game progress later is essential for many players, especially those who cannot complete the game in one session.
Estimable: No, because the level of effort required to implement game saves depends on the complexity of the game and the desired save/load functionality. It can be difficult to estimate without detailed planning and design.
Small: No, because implementing game saves can require a significant effort in terms of planning, design, and development, especially for larger games.
Testable: Yes, because the team can create test cases to ensure that the save/load functionality works correctly and does not result in any data loss or corruption.
